fields.label: BayesApp [1,2,3,4,5,Source code]

BayesApp [Hansen 2012, Source code] calculates the pair distribution, p(r), from SAXS/SANS data, generated by Bayesian indirect Fourier tranformation (BIFT) [Hansen2000, Vestergaard & Hansen, 2006].

Some basic data quality control is also possible:

  • Guinier analysis can opted for, along with Porod plot, Kratky plot and Mw calculation.
  • The errors are assessed [Larsen & Pedersen, 2021], and if over- or underestimated, rescaled data are provided. Potential outliers are also detected and can be removed.

How to use:

  • Upload data (data format: q,I,sigma).
  • For multicontrast particles with negative contrasts (e.g. micelles) you should use Transformation: Negative, else use the default positivity constraint.
  • It is recommended, but not necessary, to provide an estimate of Dmax (improves speed and accuracy).
  • Consider other options (e.g., set qmin/qmax, generate Kratky plot, make Guinier analysis, or increase number of error calculations if p(r) appears truncated at Dmax).
  • Hover the mouse over the fields for a short description.

Enjoy! Feedback welcome via the tab to the right.
Data file (columns: q,I,σ)
fields.help:
i): Format (q, I(q), error). Data points can optionally be rebinned.

ii): Text lines in the data file are ignored.

iii): Maximum dynamic range for I(q) is about 1000 using the web version due to the limited resolution of p(r).

fields.label: qmin (optional)
fields.help: Optionally enter q min - same units as the input data: 1/Å or 1/nm. default is 0 (all points included).

fields.label: qmax (optional)
fields.help: Optionally enter q max - same units the input as data: 1/Å or 1/nm. default is 10 (all points included).

fields.label: Guess of the maximum distance (optional)
fields.help:
Optionally enter an initial estimate of the maximum distance in the scatterer - same units as the input data: Å or nm.

A decent guess makes BayesApp faster and more reliable

fields.label: Fix
fields.help: Fix the value for dmax

fields.label: Transformation/Regularization
fields.values: Debye (default, p(r) with positivity constraint)~D~Negative (p(r) without positivity constraint)~N~MaxEnt (use ellipsoid as prior)~M
fields.help:
As a rule of thumb, use Negative if:

(1) there is a structure factor (e.g. electrostatic repulsion), or

(2) the particle has both positive and negative contrast (e.g. micelles or nanodiscs)

else, use Debye

All options:

[D]ebye (default -> returning p(r) with positivity constraint), sin(q*r)/(q*r) * dr

[N]egative (Debye transformation -> returning p(r) without positivity constraint), sin(q*r)/(q*r) * dr

[M]axEnt using an ellipsoid of revolution as prior ( -> p(r) -positivity constraint), sin(q*r)/(q*r) * dr

The axial ratio for the ellipsoid is optimized using the posterior probability.

fields.label: Units in data (Å or nm)
fields.help: Units of data, Å or nm (default: Å)

fields.label: Guinier analysis
fields.help: Make Guinier analysis (and get Rg_Guinier).

fields.label: Set qmaxRg in Guinier analysis
fields.help:
Set qmax*Rg in Guinier analysis, typically 1.0-1.3 (shape dependent)

Default: 1.25, Minimum 0.7, Maximum 1.35

fields.label: Skip first points in Guinier analysis (default=0)
fields.help:
Skip first points in Guinier analysis

Default: 0, Maximum 900

fields.label: Kratky plot
fields.help: Show Kratky plot (q^2*I vs q). Give idea of foldedness or unfoldedness of proteins.

fields.label: Dimensionless Kratky plot
fields.help: Make Kratky plot dimensionless (q -> q*Rg)

fields.label: Subtract constant in Kratky plot
fields.help:
Subract constant from I (I -> I-const)

Accurate background subtraction is essential for Mw determination via integral over Kratky plot

fields.label: Calculate Mw from the Kratky plot
fields.help: Using Fischer/SASMOW method. Only applicaple for pure protein samples.

fields.label: Units in data (A or nm)
fields.help:
Units of data, A or nm (default: A)

used to set the binsize correctly in pr_bin.dat

fields.label: Porod plot
fields.help: Show Porod plot (q^4*I vs q). Should be approx constant at high q (if not: adjust constant subtraction).

fields.label: Subtract constant in Porod plot
fields.help:
Subract constant from I (I -> I-const)

The Porod plot should be approx constatant at high q.

fields.label: Advanced options (if in doubt, leave as is and press Submit)
fields.help: Show more options

fields.label: Estimate of Lagrange multiplier, α
fields.help:
Optionally enter the starting value for the logarithm of the Lagrange multiplier, α (usually between -10 and 20).

Larger values will give smoother distributions or, for the MaxEnt constraint, an estimate closer to the prior ellipsoid of revolution.

fields.label: Fix
fields.help: Fix the value for α

fields.label: Fit background
fields.help: A flat background is fitted to the data (highly recommended).

fields.label: Rebin data to about this number of points
fields.help:
Optionally enter number of datapoints (rebinning data to about this number of bins) - can give significant speed-up.

Default is nrebin=500, minimum is 20, max is 9999.

IMPORTANT: the correction factor depends on the rebinning, so the output correction factor is for the rebined data.

Rebinned data and scaled and rebinned data are given as output.

fields.label: Number of points in p(r)
fields.help:
Optionally enter the number of points in the estimated function p(r): more points increase the cpu-time.

Default: 70, Minimum 20, Maximum 500

fields.label: Desmearing constant
fields.help:
Optionally enter a correction for slit smearing. Default is no smearing.

Enter value for constant c as given by the expression

I_smear(q) = integrate P(t)*I(sqrt(q**2 + t**2)) dt with the

primary beam length profile: P(t) = c/sqrt(pi) * exp(-c**2*t**2).

The fit and the deconvolution are both given in the ouput file fit.d

fields.label: Number of extra error calculations
fields.help:
Set to e.g. 500, if p(r) goes abruptly to zero

Input number of extra error calculations (max 1000).

Entering a large number will improve the error estimate,

but require more cpu time.

In some cases it may be a little tricky to obtain a decent

error estimate. Try testing a couple of values to see the effect.

fields.label: Correction of errors (optional)
fields.values: Constant (default, scale all errors with same factor)~C~Non-constant (scaling varies along q)~N~BETA:Intensity-dependent (correct errors by adding intensity-dependent term)~I
Constant (default, scale all errors with same factor)~C~Non-constant (scaling varies along q)~N
fields.help:
Give an estimate of the correction of over/underestimated errors.

(1) Constant (default): scale all errors with same factor, β=sqrt(χ2r)

(2) Non-constant: scale each Shannon channel with factor, β_i=sqrt(χ2r,i); set minimum points per channel below.

(3) Intensity-dependent: correct errors by intensity-dependent factor, σ=σ+aI

Give an estimate of the correction of over/underestimated errors.

(1) Constant (default): scale all errors with same factor, β=sqrt(χ2r)

(2) Non-constant: scale each Shannon channel with factor, β_i=sqrt(χ2r,i); set minimum points per channel below.

fields.label: Minimum bin size of one Shannon bin (default: 20, min: 10, max: 300)
fields.help:
Minimum bin size of one Shannon bin.

See Larsen and Pedersen 2021 [5]

fields.label: Plot data with log q (default: lin q)
fields.help: Plot data and fits on logarithmic q scale (default is linear q scale)

fields.label: Set p(r) bin size
fields.help:
Output pr (pr_bin.dat) interpolated on grid with fixed binsize (default = 1 A)

OBS: Ensure you have enough number of points in p(r) (set above, default is 70).

fields.label: Units in data (A or nm)
fields.help: Units of data, Å or nm (default: Å)

fields.label: Set binsize (in Å)
fields.help:
Output pr (pr_bin.dat) interpolated on grid with this binsize (default = 1 A)

default is 1, min is 0.01 and max is 10.

OBS: Ensure you have enough number of points in p(r) (set above, default is 70).

fields.label: Skip first points
fields.help: Optionally, provide a number of the first points in data to skip (will redefine qmin if more restrictive than selected qmin).

fields.label: Remove all outliers
fields.help: Remove outliers iteratively. BayesApp is run, then the worst outlier (if any is removed). This is repeated until there are no outliers left.

fields.label: pair distribution, p(r)
fields.help: The produced pair distribution, p(r)

fields.label: Fit of data
fields.help: The fit (on the same q-scale as the data).

fields.label: Data used (rebinned and in selected q-range)
fields.help: The data used, rebinned (if opted for), and in selected q-range (if opted for). If outliers are removed they will also be removed from this dataset.

fields.label: Data with rescaled errors (if over/underestimated)
fields.help:
Dataset with errors being rescaled by a correction factor. Rebinned (if opted for). Outliers removed (if opted for).

See Larsen and Pedersen 2020 [5]

fields.label: Data without worst outliers (if any)
fields.help:
Dataset with worst outlier (with highest magnitude of the normalized residual) being filtered out.

Potential outliers defined as points with p-value<0.03 with respect to p(r) fit, after multiple testing correction p=p*N, where N is the number of datapoints

fields.label: Parameters
fields.help: The parameters file

fields.label: Results zipped
fields.help: Results packaged in a zip file

fields.label: Dmax
fields.help: Maximum distance in particle - same units as the input data: Å or nm

fields.label: R<sub>g</sub> from p(r)
fields.help: Radius of gyration from p(r) - same units as the input data: Å or nm

fields.label: R<sub>g</sub> from Guinier analysis
fields.help: Radius of gyration from Guinier analysis - same units as the input data: Å or nm

fields.label: I(0) estimated
fields.help: Forward scattering

fields.label: Background (constant)
fields.help: constant background

fields.label: <hr> Error Assessment (see also runs tests below plots) <hr>
Reduced χ<sup>2</sup> (χ<sup>2</sup><sub>r</sub>)
fields.help: χ<sup>2</sup><sub>r</sub> = χ<sup>2</sup>/(M-N<sub>g</sub>-1), where M is the number of data points and N<sub>g</sub> is the number of good parameters. See Larsen and Pedersen 2020 [5]

fields.label: p-value for χ<sup>2</sup><sub>r</sub>
fields.help: probability for χ<sup>2</sup><sub>r</sub>, given correct errors. See Larsen and Pedersen 2021 [5]

fields.label: The experimental errors are probably
fields.help:
Experimental errors assessed from the χ2r. Recommended significance criteria:

the experimental errors are correctly estimated if the probability is above 0.003,

else they are likely over/underestimated and rescaled errors (in rescale.d) may be used for further data analysis.

See Larsen and Pedersen 2021 [5]

fields.label: Correction factor for errors
fields.help:
Constant rescaling (default): a constant was used to rescale errors in rescale.d, by:

σrescaled = c*σ, where c = sqrt(χ2r)

Non-constant rescaling: q-dependent factors were used to rescale errors in rescale.d (indepent in each Shannon-bin):

σrescaled,bin = cbin*σ, where cbin = sqrt(χ2r,bin)

See Larsen and Pedersen 2021 [5]

fields.label: Number of potential outliers
fields.help: Potential outlier is a datapoint with p-value below 0.03, given fit is true. After Benferroni multiple test correction p = p*N, where N is the number of data points. Data without the worst outlier (having largest magnitude of the normalized residual) is provided as outlier_filtered.dat. Consider rerunning analysis with that dataset.

fields.label: Number of good parameters, N<sub>g</sub>
fields.help: Number of good parameters is an estimate of the maksimum number of independent model parameters you can retrieve from the data. See Vestergaard and Hansen 2006 [4]

fields.label: Number of Shannon channels, N<sub>S</sub>
fields.help: Number of Shannon channels

fields.label: Longest run in data
fields.help: Longest run of model values being above or below corresponding data. Pairwize Cormap test. Franke et al 2015, Nature Methods 12: 419-422. OBS: parameters are averages of all solutions, weighted with probability, therefore this number may not be an integer.

fields.label: Theoretical expected longest run
fields.help: Expected longest run (Schilling 1990: The longest run of heads).

fields.label: p-value for longest run
fields.help: Probability of getting this longest run (or any more extreme value), given the number of data points and that model and data come from the same distribution (Schilling 1990: The longest run of heads).

fields.label: Number of runs in data
fields.help: Number of runs when comparing model and data. Wald-Wolfowitz runs test. OBS: parameters are averages of all solutions, weighted with probability, therefore this number i/ not an integer.

fields.label: Theoretical expected number of runs
fields.help: Expected number of runs (see, e.g., the Wikipedia entry on Wald-Wolfowitz runs test).

fields.label: p-value for number of runs
fields.help: Probability of getting this number of runs (or any more extreme value). Assuming number or runs are normal distributed (see, e.g., the Wikipedia entry on Wald-Wolfowitz runs test).

fields.label: Input file
fields.help: Input file (for running locally)

fields.label: Source code
fields.help: Source code (needs to be compiled)

fields.label: Terminal output
fields.help: A copy of the standard output

fields.label: Correction factors for errors
fields.help: List of factor(s) by which errors (in rescale.d) has been rescaled. See Larsen and Pedersen 2020 [5]

fields.label: log(α)
fields.help: Lagrange multiplier. χ<sup>2</sup> + α*S was minimized in the fit. S is the smoothness prior. See Hansen 2000 [1]

fields.label: Evidence at maximum
fields.help: Evidence for the solution, used to determine the most probable α. See Hansen 2000 [1]
